100% of, that very large exploration block on the west side, the Birch Mountains, the Jordan lands on the middle of the map and then the Audet
leases on the east side of the map, which have the discovered resources that I mentioned earlier. And we're going to spend a little bit of time talking
about Audet, because that's the focus of our activity right now.
So let's move on to slide 11. This is the summary of the discovered bitumen initially-in-place on the Audet lands. And this summary is from the
Sproule report that was released in October by SilverBirch, October 2011. As pointed out below that, we also have the Birch Mountains leases,
100% working interest in nine leases, 147 sections, very extensive land position, and then the Jordan leases 100% working interest in two leases
comprising 36 sections.
We'll move on to slide 12. Again, the people that are familiar with SilverBirch, this will be a familiar drawing. We are moving Audet forward towards
development, but of course we have quite a way to go yet.The 2012 winter program as I mentioned is just underway, and in addition to additional
delineation drilling, we will be doing some 2-D seismic and a key part of the program will be a cap rock evaluation. One of the important things
about the Audet lease is that we know that the cap rock is intermittent across the lease. So our focus this year is to identify an area where there's
sufficient cap rock to allow us to proceed with a conventional SAGD project.
Now we're quite confident that the resources there are based on last year's drilling program and we know that it is a very high-quality, quite thick
continuous bitumen resource. So the technical issue as far as production will be this presence of cap rock. However having said that, we also know
that there are new emerging technologies that may be applicable even if the cap rock is somewhat limited or intermittent. So we believe this whole
area has tremendous potential because of the size of the resource.
The drilling will continue through the first six to eight weeks of this year, then of course the analysis cycle goes through the geotechnical testing
of the cap rock samples, the analysis of the many frac tests that we will be doing. And then once that data is all assembled, analyzed and evaluated
by our independent assessors, we should be able to report contingent resource either by the end of this year or early in 2013.The project schedule
below is notional because of course it assumes that we are successful in proving our technical project, but one could conjecture that it would be
viable to have production from these leases by 2016 or 2017 timeframe based on normal regulatory and development cycles.
Let's move on to slide 13. So moving towards the summary here, Audet basically provides us a platform for growth, and as we mentioned that's
1.69 billion barrels of discovered resource in place, and we'll have our contingent resource by the end of this year. We'll also commence a desktop
assessment of the Birch Mountain's resources, which we-- back in the UTS days we had-- we put seven core holes into those leases on very preliminary
explorations. So in the balance of this year, we'll be doing some desktop work to identify best locations for seismic and perhaps drilling, and it'll
be later in the year before we can announce what we plan to do as far as an exploration program on those leases.
Jordan, some-- an interesting little patch of land, it's quite close to some other major projects.The eight core holes that have been drilled in to date
have indicated there's bitumen, but it's not very extensive. However, we believe that this might be an interesting opportunity for some shallow
unconventional approaches to extraction, and so we will basically look at it in that light and see how that might be taken forward. As we do this
work, of course we're open-minded to consider joint venture prospects or other approaches and looking at the best way for Silver Willow shareholders
as to how to develop these resources.
So let's move onto slide 14. So as far as financing, the initial CAD25 million will be used to finance our exploration work and analysis for the balance
of this year and of course G&A and miscellaneous expenditures. As part of the transaction,Teck has provided an interim CAD20 million loan facility
and that expires in the middle of the year, but it helps tide us over any shortfalls in cash during the closing period and shortly thereafter. So we're
looking to once again be successful with the drill bit to drive the Company forward and create the financing flexibility and strategic opportunities.
We believe that with success in the field, it'll allow us to continue to fund our objectives and to meet our exploration and development objectives.
So finally to close this part of the presentation, we believe we've completed a very successful transaction, obviously subject to closing, which should
be by the end of March. We believe we've provided a significant premium to our shareholders. Our shareholders, SilverBirch shareholders, will
receive a one for one share in the SilverWillow Company, and SilverBirch shareholders will retain the resource upside through its exposure to
SilverWillow. And your Management team is here to go to work on the SilverWillow resources. Finally, the Board of Directors has unanimously

Michael Stevens - SilverBirch Energy Corporation - Manager- Finance, IR

Q U E S T I O N S A N D A N S W E R S
Operator
Thank you, Mr. Stevens. Ladies and gentlemen, we will now conduct the question-and-answer session. (Operator Instructions) Sachin Shah with
Tullett Prebon.
Sachin Shah - Tullett Prebon - Analyst
Hi, good morning thanks for taking my question. I just wanted to go over the regulatory approvals. I did see that you're expecting this deal to close
kind of mid April, so just was wondering if you could go over that timeline? I did see here that you got some shareholders to support this transaction,
so maybe if you could just talk about the background and how you came to this transaction? I missed the first part of the call, so I apologize if you
discussed this already.
Howard Lutley - SilverBirch Energy Corporation - President, CEO
Okay. Yes, there's 39% of the shareholders, well that's basically Management's and the two major shareholders have already locked up to the deal.
As far as how the deal came together, I'm not quite sure on your question, but I'm assuming -- are you talking about timeline or --
Sachin Shah - Tullett Prebon - Analyst
Yes, so when I say deal came together like were you talking to other parties, was this an auction process, did Teck approach you, I just want to
understand was this is solely one-off situation with Teck our did the Company solicit other offers and this was the kind of best situation for SilverBirch
shareholders as well as Teck shareholders kind of a situation?
Howard Lutley - SilverBirch Energy Corporation - President, CEO
Okay, I understand that. Actually no, we've been through a long strategic process almost, actually we are pretty well 12 months now. Once SilverBirch
was formed October 2010, we basically got up and running, got settled in. And then starting in January 2011, we formed an informal strategic
working group of some of the members of the Board with also our financial advisors joined the team as well. And we basically look at the strategic
options for the Company, understanding the assets that we had. Now of course at that time, we didn't have any results from our Audet drilling
program, so we didn't know the scale of the opportunity. So during the first sort of three or four months of that strategic process, we were assessing
our assets and then getting to understand what we had on the Audet property.
So by sort of mid-year, we had some additional information.We had a pretty good understanding of the scale of the opportunity at Audet.We also
had completion of the design basis memorandum, we had the resource update from Frontier and Equinox. And probably the key factor was in end
of June, we had the revised capital cost estimates for the Frontier and Equinox projects. So again, with those bits of information, we were able to
4
THOMSON REUTERS STREETEVENTS | www.streetevents.com | Contact Us
©2012 Thomson Reuters. All rights reserved. Republication or redistribution of Thomson Reuters content, including by framing or similar means, is prohibited without
the prior written consent of Thomson Reuters. 'Thomson Reuters' and the Thomson Reuters logo are registered trademarks of Thomson Reuters and its affiliated
companies.
526
JANUARY 09, 2012 / 2:00PM, TCK.B.TO - Teck Resources Limited to acquire SilverBirch - Conference Call
get a pretty good handle on the potential economics of Frontier and Equinox as well as what the capital quantum that would be required from
SilverBirch to stay in the project at 50/50.
Now of course all along we had always said at SilverBirch that at some point we would look at our options for how great our participation in the
project would be, in the Frontier and Equinox project, and that we'd be quite open to constructive ways to reduce our interest as long as it created
value for the shareholders. Now the financial advisors also conducted a confidential low-key process of contacting potential participants who might
be willing to either participate with us, buy our share, any number of the normal kind of things you would consider and that was quite extensive,
it was international, but it wasn't a public process.
At the same time, commencing in about the mid-summer, we also started negotiations with Teck on our partnership agreement. And that had
been a long-standing commitment between both ourselves and Teck, was to form a partnership and properly paper it with a partnership agreement.
Through that process, we had to examine value, both parties examine value, and we are looking at ways to make a good agreement, having learned
a lot from our participation also with Teck in the Fort Hills agreement and recognizing that there were a few things in that agreement that hadn't
worked well for a junior partner, particularly during a financial crisis.
So we wanted to come up with a similar partnership agreement but something that provided flexibility for the smaller Company, i.e. SilverBirch.
And we work hard with Teck to put that kind of agreement together, and actually had something that we could put in front of our Boards, and
ultimately then just two days before Christmas, Teck came back with the offer that we're looking at now rather than proceed with the partnership
approach. So really it was quite a long process, talked to either ourselves or our partners, talked to a lot of different parties over that intervening
period and finally came to what we believe now is the offer we have in front-- a good offer that we have in front of us now.
Sachin Shah - Tullett Prebon - Analyst
Okay, perfect. And then just as a kind of what regulatory approvals and then kind of a potential timeline between now and kind of mid-April, I think
that's when you're expecting the deal to close on or before mid-April?
Howard Lutley - SilverBirch Energy Corporation - President, CEO
Yes. I'll answer the one I know, Jina, our Legal Counsel, is here as well, so she can fill in. But there's competition acts, is that the --
Jina Abells Morissette - SilverBirch Energy Corporation - VP - Legal and Administration
That's the only one, yes.
Howard Lutley - SilverBirch Energy Corporation - President, CEO
That's the only one.
Jina Abells Morissette - SilverBirch Energy Corporation - VP - Legal and Administration
And then it's a plan of arrangement, so we'll have to get the court order and take all of those steps. So I mean you know how it works once we mail
the circular the clock starts ticking, but because we are starting SilverWillow, the circular will have a lot of information in it about the new Company,
so that will take some time. So we're still aiming sort of for that end of March/early April closing timeframe.

JANUARY 09, 2012 / 2:00PM, TCK.B.TO - Teck Resources Limited to acquire SilverBirch - Conference Call

Mark Friesen - RBC Capital Markets - Analyst
Okay, so-- all right. So second question, perhaps explain the context of why or how Twin Lakes became part of the 100% Teck lands?
Howard Lutley - SilverBirch Energy Corporation - President, CEO
Yes, the-- it was really just a negotiation. We weren't-- we as SilverBirch didn't feel strongly about keeping Twin Lakes, our view on the geological
potential, is that it's probably limited but obviously that is SilverBirch's view and that's only subject to the limited drilling that has been done to
date. Teck was interested in keeping Twin Lakes, so it was easy for us to make that swap of those lands.
Mark Friesen - RBC Capital Markets - Analyst
Sure. Is that a read through that that's possibly a mining opportunity?
Howard Lutley - SilverBirch Energy Corporation - President, CEO
It's-- no I wouldn't say it is or and it isn't a mining opportunity, but it's certainly if there is going to be oil sand there, it would be at depths that would
be more likely a mineable prospect that an in situ prospect just because of the depth of the geology in that area.
Mark Friesen - RBC Capital Markets - Analyst
Sure, okay. And finally if you could give a little more detail as to the terms of the interim loan facility, please?
Howard Lutley - SilverBirch Energy Corporation - President, CEO
It's normal commercial terms. Wayne is sitting here, I will ask them to talk about that. There's not a whole lot about-- can be said about it I don't
think.
Wayne Bobye - SilverBirch Energy Corporation - VP, CFO
No Mark, it's just a regular loan. It's very similar to the one that we have in place now. It's put in place to provide flexibility. The rate on it is very
competitive with what we have now related to prime. And it's just put in place so that we have some flexibility going forward because we were--
if we hadn't done this transaction, we probably would've had to raise some equity, so this gives us some flexibility to move forward with our capital
spending program.
Mark Friesen - RBC Capital Markets - Analyst
Sure, what's the duration of that facility?
7

Howard Lutley - SilverBirch Energy Corporation - President, CEO

Operator
[Andrew Wryneck] with Scotia Capital.
Catharine Sterritt - Scotia Capital - Analyst
Good morning it's Catharine Sterritt. Just two questions. Just to clarify the loan facility, so the intent is that when the transaction closes, you'll use
the CAD25 million working capital funding in part to repay that facility?
Howard Lutley - SilverBirch Energy Corporation - President, CEO
Yes, but there is CAD24 million cash in SilverBirch right now. We'll also have proceeds from exercise of options, which we estimate up to now will
be about CAD22 million to SilverBirch. So that actually in the time period between now and closing, by our calculations, gives us sufficient cash to
meet current obligations and the first three months of drilling in 2012. So by closing, SilverBirch's working capital will be essentially zero. And the
CAD25 million that will be contributed by Teck will go into SilverWillow.
Now as Wayne said, the CAD20 million loan provides us the flexibility because obviously the proceeds from the exercise of options will only come
in at closing, and so if there's a shortfall on cash just due to timing reasons, because drilling programs tend to be quite financially intense if you
spend a lot of money in a hurry and the bills come in very quickly. So we're just assuming that there may be a cash shortfall and that's really what
the loan will be used for so that in theory by closing, we should have most of the CAD25 million intact once we start at SilverWillow.
Catharine Sterritt - Scotia Capital - Analyst
Okay, that makes sense, thank you. And just a question on the timing. SilverWillow is being listed, do you expect that it'll-- that it's listing will be
coincident with the closing of the transaction? Or is it possible we might see the plan of arrangement close and then a few weeks later the SilverWillow
start to trade?
Howard Lutley - SilverBirch Energy Corporation - President, CEO
I'll turn that one to Jina.

environmental park or recreation area?

another park.
Howard Lutley - SilverBirch Energy Corporation - President, CEO
Yes, that-- we didn't have anything else close to the river that I can recall.

531
JANUARY 09, 2012 / 2:00PM, TCK.B.TO - Teck Resources Limited to acquire SilverBirch - Conference Call
John Tumazos - John Tumazos Very Independent Research - Analyst
Could you update us on the lease 421 area, I didn't seem to catch which of the two Companies it would go to. Lease was already sold to Imperial.
Howard Lutley - SilverBirch Energy Corporation - President, CEO
Yes, our interest, or at least UTS' interest, was already sold to Imperial, Teck, again that would be an question for Teck, what's going on with their
interest in lease 421.
John Tumazos - John Tumazos Very Independent Research - Analyst
The apparent price in terms of cash, I'm calculating is the 435 cash plus the CAD25 million working capital or 460 divided by 1.4 billion barrels, or
CAD0.33 a barrel. And that's less than the CAD2 apparent price at the time at a lower oil price for the 20% of Fort Hills sold to Total. Now admittedly
it's not exactly apples and oranges, because the degree of engineering and permitting and preliminary construction isn't the same, but could you
talk to the six-fold difference in valuation and why you're embracing selling Frontier Equinox at one-sixth of the terms or even if you made an
adjustment for the difference in phase one-third of the terms?
Howard Lutley - SilverBirch Energy Corporation - President, CEO
Yes. No, I think that one's one we could certainly respond to. If you look, we-- the number we use is about CAD0.34 a barrel, so agree with your
calculation, we come to the number slightly differently, but it's essentially CAD0.34 a barrel. This-- if you think of Frontier and Equinox, it's very
early stage, we don't have any regulatory approval at this pace, at this point. We've literally just submitted the application, or a least Teck had, at
the end of the year last year. And where as Fort Hills had had regulatory approval in place by the time we exited that project eight years, and CAD2.8
billion had been spent by the partners. In addition, UTS had an earn in right so there was additional value in Fort Hills from the earn in.
So when you compare the metrics, it is quite a different transaction. Also keep in mind that Frontier and Equinox will not commence production
until about 2020 or 2021. And the issue that was facing SilverBirch that even prior to sanction, the partnership would have to spend CAD300 million
to CAD500 million just to get to sanction, so that's over the next three to four years. And we recognized that for us, that would be quite dilutive
with the equity we would raise, be quite dilutive for SilverBirch shareholders and that the offer finally made by Teck seemed to be quite fair and
quite reasonable and that was why we made that decision to proceed.
John Tumazos - John Tumazos Very Independent Research - Analyst
If I could be so tedious with one more question.The calculation of CAD0.34 a barrel is only the cash consideration.There is the much more difficult
question of valuing the in situ assets or in situ potential assets that Teck is swapping with you in addition to the cash consideration. Did you assess
only the cash consideration in avoidance of dilution or did you assign value to the in situ assets were the documentation and the potential recovery
rates, the existence of the bitumen and recover ability of the bitumen require I guess a greater standard of documentation because they're deeper
et cetera?
Howard Lutley - SilverBirch Energy Corporation - President, CEO
Of course the potential value of the lands played into our consideration. Because obviously we are quite optimistic about the potential of both
Audet and Birch Mountains. As far as formally assigning value, we basically for our own the calculation purposes just use the book values which
provides quite a modest amount of value. I believe by closing our book value in those various properties will be about CAD90 million. So a little
over, what's that CAD1.80 a share roughly for the book value going into SilverWillow. Now obviously how the market values that we'll get to see
in the next few days, but so it was in our calculations from the point of view of establishing total value. But as far as the metrics we've referenced,
we've only referenced the cash component, John.

Mike Dunn with FirstEnergy Capital.
Mike Dunn - FirstEnergy Capital Corp. - Analyst
Hi, good morning, everyone. I guess first question is just a follow up on your comments about the book value of the assets in SilverWillow, is that
CAD90 million, Howard, is that outside of the CAD25 million in working capital?
Howard Lutley - SilverBirch Energy Corporation - President, CEO
Yes, that's right, that excludes the working capital.
Mike Dunn - FirstEnergy Capital Corp. - Analyst
Great.
Howard Lutley - SilverBirch Energy Corporation - President, CEO
And Mike, it's a bit approximate. We-- some of that working capital-- some of that book value is dependent on what we spend at Audet in the first
three months and then if you basically sort of notionally cut off at the end of March, what we've spent on Audet will count in that book value
calculation.
Mike Dunn - FirstEnergy Capital Corp. - Analyst
I see. Okay, great. And then I just thought I'd ask, I'm not sure what you can comment on it on, but you mentioned potentially other recovery
techniques at Audet should the cap rock not prove sufficient, can you talk about what you're thinking there?
Howard Lutley - SilverBirch Energy Corporation - President, CEO
Yes, what-- so the way we're looking at it right now and we've got a bit of modeling work going on with an engineering company that should be
completed sometime in the next two or three months, is we're looking at it as a conventional SAGD. And I think as we've mentioned in previous
calls, that we did have-- we did find some pretty extensive occurrences of what we believe will be a suitable cap rock material. But what we don't
11
THOMSON REUTERS STREETEVENTS | www.streetevents.com | Contact Us
©2012 Thomson Reuters. All rights reserved. Republication or redistribution of Thomson Reuters content, including by framing or similar means, is prohibited without
the prior written consent of Thomson Reuters. 'Thomson Reuters' and the Thomson Reuters logo are registered trademarks of Thomson Reuters and its affiliated
companies.
533
JANUARY 09, 2012 / 2:00PM, TCK.B.TO - Teck Resources Limited to acquire SilverBirch - Conference Call
know is how extensive. So our opening position is if we can prove up this cap rock materials existence in a big enough area and the modeling and
the testing and the many frac tests show that it's sufficient for conventional SAGD, and I wouldn't call it a low pressure, I'd call it sort of a moderate
pressure SAGD, then that's basically a conventional approach.
So that if we find that that wouldn't necessarily be technically feasible, we would then look at other SAGD related approaches maybe with solvent
assist or low pressure SAGD as is being tried out in other places. And then a further fallback would be some of the new techniques that some of
the other companies have been talking about, perhaps with some of the electrical or other solvent assist type techniques. But certainly our focus
will for Audet be on conventional SAGD as the first case.
Mike Dunn - FirstEnergy Capital Corp. - Analyst
Great. And have you been in touch with the regulator on what I guess their current thinking is about cap rock and I'm not sure if there is any -- if
they're getting any more stringent with regards to testing over the past couple of years on that, but just comment on that?
Howard Lutley - SilverBirch Energy Corporation - President, CEO
Yes, certainly the engineering consultants that we've worked with have been involved with a number of the recent applications. And of course,
Sproule our other advisor, has been involved with a number of applications. So we are reasonably aware from the consultants of the regulatory
requirements. We recognize that there is a bit of a work in progress on how that will evolve over the next 12 to 24 months. But we're certainly
taking an approach that is relatively conservative as we consider what the operating pressures would be as we do in the current modeling. And of
course the current modeling is really just an early scoping study just to try and understand what the potential will be, there'll be further rounds of
engineering once we have the many frac tests, the rest of the data from the geotechnical program and of course more resource data.
Mike Dunn - FirstEnergy Capital Corp. - Analyst
Okay, great. Thanks, Howard, thanks.
Howard Lutley - SilverBirch Energy Corporation - President, CEO
Thanks, Mike.
Operator
And Mr. Stevens, there no further questions at this time, please continue.
Michael Stevens - SilverBirch Energy Corporation - Manager- Finance, IR
Ladies and gentlemen, this concludes the conference call for today, thank you for participating. Please disconnect your lines.

assumptions could prove inaccurate or incorrect and, therefore, there can be no assurance that the results contemplated in the forward-looking statements will be realized.

THOMSON REUTERS STREETEVENTS
EDITED BRIEF
TCK.B.TO - TECK RESOURCES LIMITED
TO ACQUIRE SILVERBIRCH -
CONFERENCE CALL
EVENT DATE/TIME: JANUARY 09, 2012 / 2:00PM GMT
OVERVIEW:
Announced an agreement for TCK.B.TO to acquire SilverBirch Energy by way of
plan of arrangement and creation of SilverWillow Energy Corporation, a new
corporation focusing on in situ oil sands opportunities. SilverBirch shareholders
will receive CAD8.50 per share in cash plus one share of SilverWillow.
THOMSON REUTERS STREETEVENTS | www.streetevents.com | Contact Us
©2012 Thomson Reuters. All rights reserved. Republication or redistribution of Thomson Reuters content, including by framing or similar means, is prohibited without
the prior written consent of Thomson Reuters. 'Thomson Reuters' and the Thomson Reuters logo are registered trademarks of Thomson Reuters and its affiliated
companies.
536
JANUARY 09, 2012 / 2:00PM, TCK.B.TO - Teck Resources Limited to acquire SilverBirch - Conference Call
CORPORATE PARTICIPANTS
Michael Stevens SilverBirch Energy Corporation - Manager- Finance, IR
Howard Lutley SilverBirch Energy Corporation - President, CEO
Jina Abells Morissette SilverBirch Energy Corporation - VP - Legal and Administration
Wayne Bobye SilverBirch Energy Corporation - VP, CFO
CONFERENCE CALL PARTICIPANTS
Sachin Shah Tullett Prebon - Analyst
Mark Friesen RBC Capital Markets - Analyst
Catharine Sterritt Scotia Capital - Analyst
John Tumazos John Tumazos Very Independent Research - Analyst
Mike Dunn FirstEnergy Capital Corp. - Analyst
OVERVIEW
Announced an agreement for TCK.B.TO to acquire SilverBirch Energy by way of plan of arrangement and creation of SilverWillow
Energy Corporation, a new corporation focusing on in situ oil sands opportunities. SilverBirch shareholders will receive CAD8.50 per
share in cash plus one share of SilverWillow.
PRESENTATION SUMMARY
I. ANNOTATION (M.S.)
A. Note:
1. Announced agreement for TCK.B.TO to acquire SilverBirch Energy by way of plan of arrangement and creation of SilverWillow
Energy Corporation, a new corporation focusing on in situ oil sands opportunities.
II. ACQUISITION OVERVIEW (H.L.)
A. Resource Disclosure:
1. When talking about SilverWillow and Audet property, will be talking about discovered bitumen initially-in-place.
B. SilverWillow Energy:
1. SilverWillow being created through plan of arrangement.
2. Construction of this transaction quite similar to the one that's done 15 months ago between UTS and Total.
3. TCK.B.TO will:
a. Acquire all of SilverBirch's common shares.
i. SilverBirch shareholders will receive CAD8.50 per share in cash plus one share of SilverWillow.
b. Contribute CAD25m in cash to SilverWillow.
c. Contribute 50% working interest in Birch Mountains and Jordan Properties (held jointly to SilverWillow).
1
THOMSON REUTERS STREETEVENTS | www.streetevents.com | Contact Us
©2012 Thomson Reuters. All rights reserved. Republication or redistribution of Thomson Reuters content, including by framing or similar means, is prohibited without
the prior written consent of Thomson Reuters. 'Thomson Reuters' and the Thomson Reuters logo are registered trademarks of Thomson Reuters and its affiliated
companies.
537
JANUARY 09, 2012 / 2:00PM, TCK.B.TO - Teck Resources Limited to acquire SilverBirch - Conference Call
4. All SilverBirch assets will be transferred to SilverWillow, except working interest in Frontier and Equinox projects and Twin
Lakes leases, which Co. will keep.
a. SilverWillow (will be focused on in situ rather than on mining) will own 100% of Audet properties, Birch Mountains leases
and Jordan leases and will be capitalized initially with CAD25m.
5. Cash component that each SilverBirch shareholder will receive is CAD8.50.
a. For each share of SilverBirch they hold, they will receive a share of SilverWillow, which will have approx. CAD0.50 of working
capital per share plus approx. 30 barrels of Discovered Resource per share in Audet property.
b. At moment, has no knowledge of resources discovered or otherwise on Birch Mountains or Jordan Properties.
c. In addition to lands described, will have 117,000 acres of exploration.
d. Based on cash component alone (cash shareholders receive plus cash going into SilverWillow), SilverBirch shareholders
will be receiving 25% premium to closing price on Jan 9 and 38% premium to 20-day volume weighted avg. price.
e. SilverBirch's board and management unanimously recommending acceptance of this offer to SilverBirch's shareholders.
i. Lock-up agreements signed including two major shareholders, West Face and The Children's Investment Fund.
C. SilverWillow:
1. As SilverBirch announced in Oct., has confirmed significant resource potential on Audet property, northeast of Fort McMurray.
a. In the field drilling.
i. Basically got started a couple of days ago with rigs turning; has additional information which by this year-end should
allow to determine contingent resources on this property.
2. Additional upside in Birch Mountains area, immediately west of Frontier.
a. Exploration lands where oil sands are little deep or buried.
b. In past couple of years, has been quite active area for exploration with number of companies with programs going on in
Birch Mountains.
3. Taking across complete management team and board from previous co., SilverBirch to SilverWillow.
4. Work plan focused on exploring these properties and then moving them forward along regulatory path and engineering
path and determining what value is and whether it makes sense to keep bouncing projects or looking for partners or looking
for constructive deals once it knows what it has and de-risked projects for possible partners.
a. Initial working capital approx. CAD25m, subject to working capital corrections and adjustments following closing.
D. Lands:
1. Lands (indiscernible) of closing, with exception of Audet's which currently SilverBirch owns 100%.
2. TCK.B.TO will have 100% of:
a. Frontier project.
b. Equinox project.
c. Twin Lakes leases just on east of Athabasca River.
3. SilverWillow will own 100% of:
a. Large exploration block on west side of Birch Mountains.
b. Jordan lands.
c. Audet leases, which have discovered resources.
E. Discovered Bitumen Initially-In-Place Summary On Audet Lands:
1. From Sproule report released by SilverBirch, Oct. 2011.
2. Birch Mountains leases:
a. 100% working interest in nine leases, 147 sections, extensive land position.
3. Jordan leases:
a. 100% working interest in two leases comprising 36 sections.
F. Audet Notional Development Plan:
1. Moving Audet forward towards development.
2. 2012 winter program just underway.
2
THOMSON REUTERS STREETEVENTS | www.streetevents.com | Contact Us
©2012 Thomson Reuters. All rights reserved. Republication or redistribution of Thomson Reuters content, including by framing or similar means, is prohibited without
the prior written consent of Thomson Reuters. 'Thomson Reuters' and the Thomson Reuters logo are registered trademarks of Thomson Reuters and its affiliated
companies.
538
JANUARY 09, 2012 / 2:00PM, TCK.B.TO - Teck Resources Limited to acquire SilverBirch - Conference Call
3. In addition to additional delineation drilling, will be doing some 2D seismic and key part of program will be cap rock
evaluation.
a. Knows cap rock is intermittent across lease.
b. Focus this year is to identify area where there is sufficient cap rock to allow to proceed with conventional (indiscernible)
project.
c. Quite confident that resources based on last year's drilling program.
d. Knows it is high quality, quite thick continuous bitumen resource.
e. Technical issue as far as production will be presence of cap rock.
f. New emerging technologies may be applicable even if cap rock is somewhat limited or intermittent.
g. Believes this whole area has tremendous potential because of resource size.
h. Drilling will continue through first 6-8 weeks of this year.
i. Analysis cycle goes through geotechnical testing of cap rock samples, analysis of mini-frac tests that will be done and
once that date is all assembled, analyzed and evaluated by independent assessors, should report contingent resource,
either by this year-end or early 2013.
4. Project schedule notional.
5. Will be viable to have production from these leases by 2016 or 2017 timeframe, based on normal regulatory and development
cycles.
6. Audet basically provides platform for growth.
a. 1.69 billion barrels of discovered resource in place.
b. Will have contingent resource by this year-end.
7. Will commence desktop assessment of Birch Mountain resources, which back in UTS days, SBE.V put seven core holes into
those leases on preliminary exploration.
a. In balance of this year, will be doing some desktop work to identify best locations for seismic and perhaps drilling.
b. Will be later in year before announcement of what it plans to do as far as exploration program on those leases.
8. Jordan:
a. Quite close to some other major projects.
b. Eight core holes drilled to date indicated there's bitumen, but it's not extensive.
c. Believes might be interesting opportunity for some shallow, unconventional approaches to extraction.
9. Open minded to consider JV prospects or other approaches and looking at best way for SilverWillow shareholders as to
how to develop these resources.
G. Financing:
1. Initial CAD25m will be used to finance exploration work and analysis for balance of this year and G&A and miscellaneous
expenditures.
2. As part of transaction, TCK.B.TO provided interim CAD20m loan facility, expiring in middle of year.
a. Helps tied SBE.V over any shortfalls in cash, during closing period and shortly thereafter.
3. Looking to once again be successful with drill bit to drive [co.] forward and create financing flexibility and strategic
opportunities.
4. Believes with success in field, will allow [SBE.V] to continue to fund objectives and meet exploration and development
objectives.
H. Summary:
1. Believes:
a. Completed successful transaction, subject to closing, which should be by March-end.
b. Provided significant premium to shareholders.
2. SilverBirch shareholders will:
a. Receive one-for-one share in SilverWillow co.
b. Retain resource upside through exposure to SilverWillow.
3. Management team to go to work on SilverWillow resources.
4. Board of Directors unanimously approved this plan.

QUESTIONS AND ANSWERS
Operator
Thank you, Mr. Stevens. Ladies and gentlemen, we will now conduct the question-and-answer session. (Operator Instructions) Sachin
Shah with Tullett Prebon.
Sachin Shah - Tullett Prebon - Analyst
Hi, good morning thanks for taking my question. I just wanted to go over the regulatory approvals. I did see that you're expecting
this deal to close kind of mid April, so just was wondering if you could go over that timeline? I did see here that you got some
shareholders to support this transaction, so maybe if you could just talk about the background and how you came to this transaction?
I missed the first part of the call, so I apologize if you discussed this already.
Howard Lutley - SilverBirch Energy Corporation - President, CEO
Okay. Yes, there's 39% of the shareholders, well that's basically Management's and the two major shareholders have already locked
up to the deal. As far as how the deal came together, I'm not quite sure on your question, but I'm assuming -- are you talking about
timeline or --
Sachin Shah - Tullett Prebon - Analyst
Yes, so when I say deal came together like were you talking to other parties, was this an auction process, did Teck approach you, I
just want to understand was this is solely one-off situation with Teck our did the Company solicit other offers and this was the kind
of best situation for SilverBirch shareholders as well as Teck shareholders kind of a situation?
Howard Lutley - SilverBirch Energy Corporation - President, CEO
Okay, I understand that. Actually no, we've been through a long strategic process almost, actually we are pretty well 12 months now.
Once SilverBirch was formed October 2010, we basically got up and running, got settled in. And then starting in January 2011, we
formed an informal strategic working group of some of the members of the Board with also our financial advisors joined the team
as well. And we basically look at the strategic options for the Company, understanding the assets that we had. Now of course at that
time, we didn't have any results from our Audet drilling program, so we didn't know the scale of the opportunity. So during the first
sort of three or four months of that strategic process, we were assessing our assets and then getting to understand what we had on
the Audet property.
So by sort of mid-year, we had some additional information. We had a pretty good understanding of the scale of the opportunity at
Audet. We also had completion of the design basis memorandum, we had the resource update from Frontier and Equinox. And
probably the key factor was in end of June, we had the revised capital cost estimates for the Frontier and Equinox projects. So again,
with those bits of information, we were able to get a pretty good handle on the potential economics of Frontier and Equinox as well
as what the capital quantum that would be required from SilverBirch to stay in the project at 50/50.
Now of course all along we had always said at SilverBirch that at some point we would look at our options for how great our
participation in the project would be, in the Frontier and Equinox project, and that we'd be quite open to constructive ways to reduce
our interest as long as it created value for the shareholders. Now the financial advisors also conducted a confidential low-key process
4
THOMSON REUTERS STREETEVENTS | www.streetevents.com | Contact Us
©2012 Thomson Reuters. All rights reserved. Republication or redistribution of Thomson Reuters content, including by framing or similar means, is prohibited without
the prior written consent of Thomson Reuters. 'Thomson Reuters' and the Thomson Reuters logo are registered trademarks of Thomson Reuters and its affiliated
companies.
540
JANUARY 09, 2012 / 2:00PM, TCK.B.TO - Teck Resources Limited to acquire SilverBirch - Conference Call
of contacting potential participants who might be willing to either participate with us, buy our share, any number of the normal
kind of things you would consider and that was quite extensive, it was international, but it wasn't a public process.
At the same time, commencing in about the mid-summer, we also started negotiations with Teck on our partnership agreement.
And that had been a long-standing commitment between both ourselves and Teck, was to form a partnership and properly paper
it with a partnership agreement. Through that process, we had to examine value, both parties examine value, and we are looking
at ways to make a good agreement, having learned a lot from our participation also with Teck in the Fort Hills agreement and
recognizing that there were a few things in that agreement that hadn't worked well for a junior partner, particularly during a financial
crisis.
So we wanted to come up with a similar partnership agreement but something that provided flexibility for the smaller Company,
i.e. SilverBirch. And we work hard with Teck to put that kind of agreement together, and actually had something that we could put
in front of our Boards, and ultimately then just two days before Christmas, Teck came back with the offer that we're looking at now
rather than proceed with the partnership approach. So really it was quite a long process, talked to either ourselves or our partners,
talked to a lot of different parties over that intervening period and finally came to what we believe now is the offer we have in front--
a good offer that we have in front of us now.
Sachin Shah - Tullett Prebon - Analyst
Okay, perfect. And then just as a kind of what regulatory approvals and then kind of a potential timeline between now and kind of
mid-April, I think that's when you're expecting the deal to close on or before mid-April?
Howard Lutley - SilverBirch Energy Corporation - President, CEO
Yes. I'll answer the one I know, Jina, our Legal Counsel, is here as well, so she can fill in. But there's competition acts, is that the --
Jina Abells Morissette - SilverBirch Energy Corporation - VP - Legal and Administration

That's the only one.
Jina Abells Morissette - SilverBirch Energy Corporation - VP - Legal and Administration
And then it's a plan of arrangement, so we'll have to get the court order and take all of those steps. So I mean you know how it works
once we mail the circular the clock starts ticking, but because we are starting SilverWillow, the circular will have a lot of information
in it about the new Company, so that will take some time. So we're still aiming sort of for that end of March/early April closing
timeframe.
Sachin Shah - Tullett Prebon - Analyst
Okay. And as far as regulatory approval on competition Canada, you're-- I mean this it seems pretty much not an issue, but is that
the case, as a confirmation?

the geological potential, is that it's probably limited but obviously that is SilverBirch's view and that's only subject to the limited
drilling that has been done to date.Teck was interested in keeping Twin Lakes, so it was easy for us to make that swap of those lands.
Mark Friesen - RBC Capital Markets - Analyst
Sure. Is that a read through that that's possibly a mining opportunity?
Howard Lutley - SilverBirch Energy Corporation - President, CEO
It's-- no I wouldn't say it is or and it isn't a mining opportunity, but it's certainly if there is going to be oil sand there, it would be at
depths that would be more likely a mineable prospect that an in situ prospect just because of the depth of the geology in that area.
Mark Friesen - RBC Capital Markets - Analyst
Sure, okay. And finally if you could give a little more detail as to the terms of the interim loan facility, please?
Howard Lutley - SilverBirch Energy Corporation - President, CEO
It's normal commercial terms. Wayne is sitting here, I will ask them to talk about that. There's not a whole lot about-- can be said
about it I don't think.
Wayne Bobye - SilverBirch Energy Corporation - VP, CFO
No Mark, it's just a regular loan. It's very similar to the one that we have in place now. It's put in place to provide flexibility. The rate
on it is very competitive with what we have now related to prime. And it's just put in place so that we have some flexibility going
forward because we were-- if we hadn't done this transaction, we probably would've had to raise some equity, so this gives us some
flexibility to move forward with our capital spending program.
Mark Friesen - RBC Capital Markets - Analyst
Sure, what's the duration of that facility?

Operator
[Andrew Wryneck] with Scotia Capital.
Catharine Sterritt - Scotia Capital - Analyst
Good morning it's Catharine Sterritt. Just two questions. Just to clarify the loan facility, so the intent is that when the transaction
closes, you'll use the CAD25 million working capital funding in part to repay that facility?
Howard Lutley - SilverBirch Energy Corporation - President, CEO
Yes, but there is CAD24 million cash in SilverBirch right now. We'll also have proceeds from exercise of options, which we estimate
up to now will be about CAD22 million to SilverBirch. So that actually in the time period between now and closing, by our calculations,
gives us sufficient cash to meet current obligations and the first three months of drilling in 2012. So by closing, SilverBirch's working
capital will be essentially zero. And the CAD25 million that will be contributed by Teck will go into SilverWillow.
Now as Wayne said, the CAD20 million loan provides us the flexibility because obviously the proceeds from the exercise of options
will only come in at closing, and so if there's a shortfall on cash just due to timing reasons, because drilling programs tend to be
quite financially intense if you spend a lot of money in a hurry and the bills come in very quickly. So we're just assuming that there
may be a cash shortfall and that's really what the loan will be used for so that in theory by closing, we should have most of the CAD25
million intact once we start at SilverWillow.
Catharine Sterritt - Scotia Capital - Analyst
Okay, that makes sense, thank you. And just a question on the timing. SilverWillow is being listed, do you expect that it'll-- that it's
listing will be coincident with the closing of the transaction? Or is it possible we might see the plan of arrangement close and then
a few weeks later the SilverWillow start to trade?
Howard Lutley - SilverBirch Energy Corporation - President, CEO
I'll turn that one to Jina.

JANUARY 09, 2012 / 2:00PM, TCK.B.TO - Teck Resources Limited to acquire SilverBirch - Conference Call
John Tumazos - John Tumazos Very Independent Research - Analyst
Could you update us on the lease 421 area, I didn't seem to catch which of the two Companies it would go to. Lease was already
sold to Imperial.
Howard Lutley - SilverBirch Energy Corporation - President, CEO
Yes, our interest, or at least UTS' interest, was already sold to Imperial, Teck, again that would be an question for Teck, what's going
on with their interest in lease 421.
John Tumazos - John Tumazos Very Independent Research - Analyst
The apparent price in terms of cash, I'm calculating is the 435 cash plus the CAD25 million working capital or 460 divided by 1.4
billion barrels, or CAD0.33 a barrel. And that's less than the CAD2 apparent price at the time at a lower oil price for the 20% of Fort
Hills sold to Total. Now admittedly it's not exactly apples and oranges, because the degree of engineering and permitting and
preliminary construction isn't the same, but could you talk to the six-fold difference in valuation and why you're embracing selling
Frontier Equinox at one-sixth of the terms or even if you made an adjustment for the difference in phase one-third of the terms?
Howard Lutley - SilverBirch Energy Corporation - President, CEO
Yes. No, I think that one's one we could certainly respond to. If you look, we-- the number we use is about CAD0.34 a barrel, so agree
with your calculation, we come to the number slightly differently, but it's essentially CAD0.34 a barrel. This-- if you think of Frontier
and Equinox, it's very early stage, we don't have any regulatory approval at this pace, at this point. We've literally just submitted the
application, or a least Teck had, at the end of the year last year. And where as Fort Hills had had regulatory approval in place by the
time we exited that project eight years, and CAD2.8 billion had been spent by the partners. In addition, UTS had an earn in right so
there was additional value in Fort Hills from the earn in.
So when you compare the metrics, it is quite a different transaction. Also keep in mind that Frontier and Equinox will not commence
production until about 2020 or 2021. And the issue that was facing SilverBirch that even prior to sanction, the partnership would
have to spend CAD300 million to CAD500 million just to get to sanction, so that's over the next three to four years. And we recognized
that for us, that would be quite dilutive with the equity we would raise, be quite dilutive for SilverBirch shareholders and that the
offer finally made by Teck seemed to be quite fair and quite reasonable and that was why we made that decision to proceed.
John Tumazos - John Tumazos Very Independent Research - Analyst
If I could be so tedious with one more question.The calculation of CAD0.34 a barrel is only the cash consideration.There is the much
more difficult question of valuing the in situ assets or in situ potential assets that Teck is swapping with you in addition to the cash
consideration. Did you assess only the cash consideration in avoidance of dilution or did you assign value to the in situ assets were
the documentation and the potential recovery rates, the existence of the bitumen and recover ability of the bitumen require I guess
a greater standard of documentation because they're deeper et cetera?
Howard Lutley - SilverBirch Energy Corporation - President, CEO
Of course the potential value of the lands played into our consideration. Because obviously we are quite optimistic about the potential
of both Audet and Birch Mountains. As far as formally assigning value, we basically for our own the calculation purposes just use the
book values which provides quite a modest amount of value. I believe by closing our book value in those various properties will be

Mike Dunn - FirstEnergy Capital Corp. - Analyst

Mike Dunn - FirstEnergy Capital Corp. - Analyst
I see. Okay, great. And then I just thought I'd ask, I'm not sure what you can comment on it on, but you mentioned potentially other
recovery techniques at Audet should the cap rock not prove sufficient, can you talk about what you're thinking there?
11
THOMSON REUTERS STREETEVENTS | www.streetevents.com | Contact Us
©2012 Thomson Reuters. All rights reserved. Republication or redistribution of Thomson Reuters content, including by framing or similar means, is prohibited without
the prior written consent of Thomson Reuters. 'Thomson Reuters' and the Thomson Reuters logo are registered trademarks of Thomson Reuters and its affiliated
companies.
547
JANUARY 09, 2012 / 2:00PM, TCK.B.TO - Teck Resources Limited to acquire SilverBirch - Conference Call
Howard Lutley - SilverBirch Energy Corporation - President, CEO
Yes, what-- so the way we're looking at it right now and we've got a bit of modeling work going on with an engineering company
that should be completed sometime in the next two or three months, is we're looking at it as a conventional SAGD. And I think as
we've mentioned in previous calls, that we did have-- we did find some pretty extensive occurrences of what we believe will be a
suitable cap rock material. But what we don't know is how extensive. So our opening position is if we can prove up this cap rock
materials existence in a big enough area and the modeling and the testing and the many frac tests show that it's sufficient for
conventional SAGD, and I wouldn't call it a low pressure, I'd call it sort of a moderate pressure SAGD, then that's basically a conventional
approach.
So that if we find that that wouldn't necessarily be technically feasible, we would then look at other SAGD related approaches maybe
with solvent assist or low pressure SAGD as is being tried out in other places. And then a further fallback would be some of the new
techniques that some of the other companies have been talking about, perhaps with some of the electrical or other solvent assist
type techniques. But certainly our focus will for Audet be on conventional SAGD as the first case.
Mike Dunn - FirstEnergy Capital Corp. - Analyst
Great. And have you been in touch with the regulator on what I guess their current thinking is about cap rock and I'm not sure if
there is any -- if they're getting any more stringent with regards to testing over the past couple of years on that, but just comment
on that?
Howard Lutley - SilverBirch Energy Corporation - President, CEO
Yes, certainly the engineering consultants that we've worked with have been involved with a number of the recent applications.
And of course, Sproule our other advisor, has been involved with a number of applications. So we are reasonably aware from the
consultants of the regulatory requirements. We recognize that there is a bit of a work in progress on how that will evolve over the
next 12 to 24 months. But we're certainly taking an approach that is relatively conservative as we consider what the operating
pressures would be as we do in the current modeling. And of course the current modeling is really just an early scoping study just
to try and understand what the potential will be, there'll be further rounds of engineering once we have the many frac tests, the rest
of the data from the geotechnical program and of course more resource data.
Mike Dunn - FirstEnergy Capital Corp. - Analyst
Okay, great. Thanks, Howard, thanks.
Howard Lutley - SilverBirch Energy Corporation - President, CEO
Thanks, Mike.
Operator
And Mr. Stevens, there no further questions at this time, please continue.

Michael Stevens - SilverBirch Energy Corporation - Manager- Finance, IR
Ladies and gentlemen, this concludes the conference call for today, thank you for participating. Please disconnect your lines.
D I S C L A I M E R

In the conference calls upon which Event Briefs are based, companies may make projections or other forward-looking statements regarding a variety of items. Such forward-looking statements are based upon current
expectations and involve risks and uncertainties. Actual results may differ materially from those stated in any forward-looking statement based on a number of important factors and risks, which are more specifically
identified in the companies' most recent SEC filings. Although the companies may indicate and believe that the assumptions underlying the forward-looking statements are reasonable, any of the assumptions could
prove inaccurate or incorrect and, therefore, there can be no assurance that the results contemplated in the forward-looking statements will be realized.

THOMSON REUTERS STREETEVENTS
EDITED TRANSCRIPT
EXXI - ENERGY XXI (BERMUDA) LTD AT
PRITCHARD CAPITAL PARTNERS LLC
"ENERGIZE` CONFERENCE
EVENT DATE/TIME: JANUARY 05, 2012 / 10:05PM GMT
THOMSON REUTERS STREETEVENTS | www.streetevents.com | Contact Us
©2012 Thomson Reuters. All rights reserved. Republication or redistribution of Thomson Reuters content, including by framing or similar means, is prohibited without
the prior written consent of Thomson Reuters. 'Thomson Reuters' and the Thomson Reuters logo are registered trademarks of Thomson Reuters and its affiliated
companies.
550
JANUARY 05, 2012 / 10:05PM, EXXI - ENERGY XXI (BERMUDA) LTD at Pritchard Capital Partners LLC "Energize`
Conference
C O R P O R A T E P A R T I C I P A N T S
Stephen Berman Pritchard Capital - Analyst
Stewart Lawrence ENERGY XXI - VP IR & Communications
P R E S E N T A T I O N
Stephen Berman - Pritchard Capital - Analyst
All right. Everyone quiet down. We're going to get started with our next presentation. We're pleased to have Energy XXI. Stewart Lawrence, he's
going to be up here representing the Company today. With that, I will turn it over.
Stewart Lawrence - ENERGY XXI - VP IR & Communications
Short and sweet. Thanks, Stephen. Thanks, Pritchard, for this opportunity. It's always good.
I'll walk you through Energy XXI, what we've got going on today real quick, just a quick snapshot of the Company. We're going right on sixth
anniversary actually as an operating company. In that short time, we have built it into an almost $3 billion market cap company. We're the third
largest producer in the Gulf of Mexico shelf, primarily producing oil; about two-thirds of that is oil. The latest quarter, the September quarter,
produced just shy of 41,000 BOE a day and we're on target to show some good growth in the December quarter as we've told people.
Again, oil focused, producing oil that's getting a nice premium, not just WTI but actually premium to Brent. So today we're getting about $115 a
barrel for oil and spinning off cash flow at an amazing pace.
A quick look at where those properties are. We set out to build the Company as an acquire and exploit model chasing after large, mature oilfields
with the thought being not so much that we were bullish oil, although we have all always have been, but as engineers we can get a lot more out
of an old, a big old oil field than you can get out of a natural gas field, particularly in smaller fields as well because the big fields give you an
opportunity to drain an undrained fault block that is meaningful whereas a small one obviously is not worth your time. So we've been very successful
with that.
You can see the properties are all located on the Gulf of Mexico shelf, offshore, primarily all offshore Louisiana. It's not by chance that's where the
oil tends to be because the dump of the Mississippi River. So you can see the fields in green are oil and the few in red as well. Of course, we're
drilling some very highly prospective natural gas wells with the McMoRan partnership right now that could certainly make us more gassy in the
future but we're okay with the giant size of the targets you've got there in the economics involved.
But bottom line, we operate six of the 11 largest oilfields in the Gulf of Mexico shelf and have an interest in a seventh. So you can see that the
original focus is paying off very well.
On a proved reserves basis, we're just shy of 117 million barrels of oil equivalent with a present value run on recent strip in excess of our current
market cap alone, not to mention the value the probables and possibles that we have captured in addition.
I would highlight the value of some of those probables particularly is extraordinary because more than a third of those are associated with currently
producing well bores, which means essentially you don't spend another dime to move those volumes from probable into proved. As you produce,
you are proved and the water contact hasn't been hit yet. Those probable volumes move into the proved category.
You can see what we have been able to do over the time organically and of course through acquisitions, the most recently being December 17,
2010 just over a year ago then, the Exxon Mobil properties. I'll talk quite a bit about those core properties as we go through.
1
THOMSON REUTERS STREETEVENTS | www.streetevents.com | Contact Us
©2012 Thomson Reuters. All rights reserved. Republication or redistribution of Thomson Reuters content, including by framing or similar means, is prohibited without
the prior written consent of Thomson Reuters. 'Thomson Reuters' and the Thomson Reuters logo are registered trademarks of Thomson Reuters and its affiliated
companies.
551
JANUARY 05, 2012 / 10:05PM, EXXI - ENERGY XXI (BERMUDA) LTD at Pritchard Capital Partners LLC "Energize`
Conference
Looking to the drilling program then and what we're trying to deliver this year, you can see we've got a $450 million capital program underway,
the majority of which goes to the drill complete and to facilities, so call it $375 million of that, with a fairly even breakdown of the cash going to
the newly acquired Exxon properties, the ultradeep partnership that we've got going on with McMoRan and then our older legacy properties in
addition.Then look at it another way in terms of development versus exploration, you can see that less than a third of that is going to the higher-risk
exploration.
Now, what does that capital program get you? We've taken a longer-term view of this, of the capital spending levels and what we expect it to
deliver. Again, as I said, fiscal year '12, I should've pointed that out, we're a June 30 year-end, so we just hit the halfway point of our fiscal year. That
program is $450 million. You can see the kind of volumes that it is expected to deliver. We said an average of 46,000 to 50,000 BOE a day is the
expectation for the current fiscal year.
But importantly then you have to tie that into what it is expected to deliver on a free cash flow basis. This one typically needs some explanation
because it's kind of hard to get through your head that the more you spend on the capital program, the more free cash flow we actually generate
to pay down debt during that current year. That's -- not a lot of people have that opportunity to do it. That's a function of the projects that we're
chasing, some of which have two-month payouts, but on average we're getting about six to seven months on the overall program of when you
put the money in to when you get it all back and start generating free cash flow. So in other words, if we spend $10 million on a project, you get
that $10 million back within the next six months and then the rest of the year you are just free cash flow and able to pay down debt.
Now, in that scenario, obviously I think the question that arises is, well, why don't you spend every single penny that you generate? The fact is then
you get organizationally limited. The number of teams that we have onboard and their ability to run rigs, we've gone through it and said really
right about now the $600 million is about the maximum we think we could put to work again with the teams we have in place today.We'll evaluate
going forward whether we want to grow the team and grow the capital program even bigger. But anyway, that's where we're focused right now,
about $450 million this year, should generate to just shy, or actually the way things are going with oil prices, at or more than $400 million of free
cash flow in the current fiscal year and levering that up to even more in the coming years.
So, part of that then -- let's look at the rig activity, what we've got going on.We're getting very active right now.The ones at the top in the greenish
hue are the rigs that we operate. We've got going four rigs drilling right now, two of them at Grand Isle; one of them is a platform rig doing a
multi-well development program. Then we've just recently spud the Winters well and I will show you that in a little bit. And over at West Delta 73
we've just recently spud the Magnum well and that's coming on. Then we've got an exploration well we're 100% drilling Bullfrog. We're hoping to
have that one done by the end of this month maybe or early February.
From there then, we've got some ultra-deep exploration wells that have been going on. I'll talk to those in more detail, but Davy Jones #1 we're in
the process of completing that well right now. That's the first big discovery and this will be the first one ever online. Then we also have the Lafitte
well drilling ultra-deep, and Blackbeard East, and we just put out some news on those as well. Then the Blackbeard West shallow -- that is the
Blackbeard West #2 well, targeting a shallower zone that we saw at Blackbeard East and have been able to trace over to the Blackbeard West block,
and so we're going after that. I will tell you a little bit more of that.
then the last one going is actually Eugene Island 330.That is Apache operated. Again, that is one of the seven largest oilfields on the Gulf of Mexico
shelf.
This gives a little more granularity to it in terms of when we're drilling what, but this is the entire drilling program that we have in place through
the end of June. You can see that, again, we're getting to be very busy part of the stage. In fact, the only well in here drilled so far in the entire
program in terms of a drill well, not recompletions, is Sunny. I will talk about that, but it came on way ahead of expectations. It would be a really
nice reserve add.
Looked at another way, you can see the 2012 program on this inventory list. Again, maybe showing the ones I just showed you on the drill schedule,
but then looking out, you can see that we've got years of drilling opportunities already lined out. This only takes you through what preliminarily
we're looking through 2015, but we've got another almost 100 opportunities that -- and inventory that should give us organic growth opportunities
for years to come. That is something new for the Company.
2
THOMSON REUTERS STREETEVENTS | www.streetevents.com | Contact Us

JANUARY 05, 2012 / 10:05PM, EXXI - ENERGY XXI (BERMUDA) LTD at Pritchard Capital Partners LLC "Energize`
Conference
You know, when we started, it was an acquire and exploit and, yes, you could grow reserves beyond what you bought, further developing it, but
it was tough to actually grow the Company outside of doing additional acquisitions.
We're at a new place now. Those Exxon properties have given us drilling opportunities that should provide organic growth without acquisitions
for as far out as the eye can see. That doesn't mean we're out of the acquisition business, but we don't have a gun to our head to do it and we can
do things strategically if and when they come around.
Okay, looking then specifically at some of the core properties, the Main Pass area is the largest complex within the portfolio. It's one of the oldest
fields out there, the largest fields, part of it discovered in '76 and the other part in 2000, produced almost 100 million barrels of oil in 338 billion
cubic feet with a lot of upside left to go. In fact, you can see from when we acquired the field initially in 2007 through the end of our last fiscal year,
we had grown the reserve 64% from what initially we said we acquired. So it's been a great success story with a lot of upside yet to go.
Then looking at this year's capital program, what we have done there, the Ashton and Onyx wells were drilled using reprocessed seismic on the
sub salt, redefined the salt model entirely and it came in -- those lows came in great, producing a lot of oil. Particularly with Onyx, it has been just
amazing, came on 2200 barrels of a day of oil and it is just holding steady.
Then the other big one then will be Bullfrog where we would expect some very good rates on that well. It is an offset to a discovery nearby.
At South Pass 89, this is the 11th largest oilfield on the shelf. It has produced 192 million barrels of oil and almost 1 trillion cubic feet of gas with a
lot of upside yet to go. This shows our initial activity. This is where we focused right away when we acquired the Exxon properties because there
was a recompletion program ready to go that they had identified and we kind of fast-forwarded it all. But you can see the tremendous results here
in growing the volumes from where it was below 1000 barrels a day when we bought it, or at least when we acquired the operations, operational
control, to current, which is pushing above 5500 barrels a day. So tremendous growth here with an average payout for this program of under four
months.
Looking now at Grand Isle 16 and 18, this is a big one. This is the fifth largest oilfield on the shelf with 380 million barrels of oil already produced
and almost 1 trillion cubic feet of gas. This is where we drilled the very first well on the Exxon property, Sunny -- and I'll show you that in a second
-- and where we're drilling Winters right now with Costello and Big Abbott yet to come.
So looking at the activity already to date, you can see that we finished quite a few recompletions and workovers and have boosted those volumes
tremendously. The Sunny well again was a very nice success where we identified two additional big sands that we hadn't even seen going into it.
In fact, the sand that we went to drill forward we don't even have on production. It's completed and ready to come on when these lower zones
deplete. So it's been a great success and probably about a 1 million barrel add to proved reserves for about $10 million drilling complete.
As you can see, we've got continued drilling going on that. Winters just started and then Costello yet to come in the January time frame. This is a
quick look then at the log that I was talking about at Sunny and some of the details there. Again, old established field. We're only talk about 8300
feet to total drill in shallow water, so very inexpensive to drill complete and the payout on this is pretty close to immediate.
The Winters well, again, is the one we just spud and it's in offset to existing production in the K2 Sands. We would expect to get a pretty high IP
rate on this well given the type of sands that we're looking at. 3400 barrels a day, that would be a very nice addition. Costello again to come after
that with about 1000 barrels a day expected production just going updip, kind of amplitude supported here across the fault.
The West Delta 73, the seventh largest oilfield on the shelf, and again, with a lot of activity planned. The very first drill prospect on that is Magnum.
That is in progress now and just spud. You can see we've got several additional wells that we'll be pursuing on this with expectations of adding
more than 5000 barrels a day from this work.
Magnum I will point out real quick within West Delta 73, if this shows us what we think it's going to show us, particularly in the F-35 sand, which is
mapped here, you could open up additional opportunities, including horizontal drilling within this field. It's pretty amazing to think about. Actually
this is a 7000 acre structure just within this F-35 sand that has a total of 200 feet of relief from the top of the structure to the bottom. You have to
3
THOMSON REUTERS STREETEVENTS | www.streetevents.com | Contact Us

JANUARY 05, 2012 / 10:05PM, EXXI - ENERGY XXI (BERMUDA) LTD at Pritchard Capital Partners LLC "Energize`
Conference
be able to picture that standing within a 7000 acre field call it, so as far as the eye can see in either direction, and it would look as flat as this tabletop
over here to you. That's one big, flat, general structure. When you have something like that, you can run laterals, and instead of having 1000 barrels
a day production, then you can get it up to 4000, 5000 for not all that much additional cost. So we'll see. We'll drill two vertical wells first and then
take it from there to proceed potentially with the horizontal drilling, which all by the way speaks to significant additional recovery of original oil in
place that could be very meaningful to reserve adds.
South Timbalier 54 is another big old oilfield, and we're getting going on that right now. We just completed the first recompletion. That came on
very nicely, planned IP on that net to us was 725 BOE.You can see it came in at 1100 BOE, so very good initial success.We've got another recompletion
scheduled for January and then we've got three development drill wells planned for that field, the first one being Camshaft, which is targeting
updip and fault separated production from known existing production. It should come on at pretty strong rates, 1700 BOE a day type target there,
drilling to 12,000 feet.
So that covers the bread and butter. That covers the four properties that we're talking low risk kind of work to do that is delivering volume growth
and with opportunities continue to do so for years down the road and spinning off a tremendous amount of free cash flow. Part of that free cash
flow then we're redeploying back into the ultradeep partnership with McMoRan.
This slide here is a depiction of the basic concept of what we're doing. We're chasing fields that were huge historic producers onshore and then
subsequently the same sands were found out in deepwater and have been very prolific discoveries out there. We've just brought that back onto
the Gulf of Mexico shallow-water shelf and in fact, as I will show you, we're starting to take it even onshore in the sort of transition zone that hadn't
been drilled to date. So it's a concept that is working so far phenomenally.We only have five wells into this area of the earth of that has never been
tested before, and everything is pointing in the right direction.
The first part, Davy Jones, has been catching all the headlines because, again, this will be the Proof of Concept when we do flow. We'll get a lot of
data off this well that will be critical, particularly to the future development plans at Davy Jones, which we see as about a 6 trillion cubic feet base
case discovery, but also what it means going forward for the entire ultradeep program. So the completion is underway on this well. We've had a
couple of delays, nothing significant really, but everybody is anxious to get this on and see what it is going to do. The most recent delay was
announced this morning.We've lost a part of a motor.We're drilling this with a turbine bit that is powered by a mud pump.That mud pump decided
to fall apart, so there are pieces of the pump in the wellbore. We have to go down and fish it out. It's not a huge deal, but it is a little bit of a delay,
nothing significant. We're talking days or weeks, not months, on that.
So, where we are on that is, once we get the junk out of the well, we've got about 5000 feet more of wellbore to clean out, the cement that we left
in behind when we came out of the well to prepare it for completion. We'll get that cleaned out, run the pack or the tubulars and install the
equipment, put the perf gun in there, seal it up and get ready to pop it and flow. So it's not far away; you've got to have some patience. There has
been no big issues in there that anybody needs to worry about.
But a little bit of history then on what we have found there. Again, it's about a 20,000-acre structure and Davy Jones well #1 was drilled to just over
29,000 feet, found 20 feet of Wilcox pay. Again, that production is expected on very soon. We then stepped out and drilled an offset 2, 2.5 miles
away and found the same Wilcox Sands of 120 net feet, so proving the continuity of the sands across this major structure, but then we were able
to go deeper and through the Tuscaloosa Sands and the lower Cretaceous. So, those are additions to the original discovery. Yet to see just what
that means in terms of additional resource. The potential is huge. We will work to complete this well in the second half of this year, this calendar
year. We'll just see what we can get from those lower zones. We know we've got a nice well in terms of confirming the Wilcox but we'll see if we
can get anything out of the Cretaceous and the Tuscaloosa there.
On Blackbeard, a summary. This is just a quick look at the whole area with Blackbeard East. As I'll talk about here in a second, Blackbeard West, the
initial well that we went into with McMoRan and then now the Blackbeard West shallow well. I'll talk a little bit about Blackbeard East, of what we
found in the upper and middle Miocene Sands that surprised us. Some very nice-looking pay there at Blackbeard East that we had not expected
at all. We had it modeled as salt and it turned out to be very high-quality Sands. So then with that knowledge, we could take it across the other
prospects and say where else might we be able to reach these shallow sands. We identified Blackbeard West, this shallow area, as a key potential
there. So that well is drilling below 11,700 feet right now with a proposed target depth of 26,000 feet.
4
THOMSON REUTERS STREETEVENTS | www.streetevents.com | Contact Us

the prior written consent of Thomson Reuters. 'Thomson Reuters' and the Thomson Reuters logo are registered trademarks of Thomson Reuters and its affiliated
